original_conversation.content: [exhausted] Two hundred jobs. [pause] I keep saying it out loud because I can't quite... I mean, we actually did it. [chuckle] God, when I first proposed this whole economic development officer thing, the town council looked at me like I was, um, completely delusional. [frustrated] They kept saying we didn't have the budget, didn't have the resources. [sigh] But I knew—I just knew if we could get someone dedicated to bringing businesses here, it would work. [passionately] Our town was dying! [shaky voice] The mill closed five years ago, and families were just... leaving. [pause] My own sister moved her kids to Columbus because there was nothing here. [very quietly] Nothing. [relieved] And now? [laugh] Now we've got that distribution center opening next month, the tech startup that's renovating the old bank building, and—oh man—the manufacturing plant. [very excited] That's 120 jobs right there! [warm] Mrs. Peterson came up to me yesterday crying because her son can finally move back home. [sniffle] He's been in Detroit for three years. [pause] I think that's when it hit me, you know? [emotional] This isn't just about numbers on a spreadsheet. [slowly] These are real families who can stay together. [very sincerely] Kids who'll grow up knowing their grandparents. [happy] We saved this place.

subject: The economic development officer initiative you championed brought 200 jobs to your struggling hometown
